title: Defining the Genre
desc:
The start of the 20th century was defined by social unrest and global anxiety brought by the First World War and the Russian Revolution. There was also a widespread political tensions that caused the rise of totalitarian regimes and oligarchies that held control over the masses.

In this era, dystopian themes centered around politics ruled by the few and caste system where the lower class is subjected to oppressive actions by the upper class.

books.title: The Iron Heel
books.author: Jack London
books.desc: 'The Iron Heel' describes a world in which the division between the classes has deepened, creating a powerful Oligarchy that retains control through terror.

books.title: We
books.author: Yevgeny Zamyatin
books.desc: In a glass-enclosed city of absolute straight lines, ruled over by the all-powerful 'Benefactor', the citizens of the totalitarian society of OneState live out lives devoid of passion and creativity

title: Loss of Individuality and Rise of Totalitarianism
desc:
Political tensions and global anxieties worsen as the 1930s began. This period was defined by the rise of the Nazi Party headed by Adolf Hitler. Millions of Jews perished in the Holocaust and millions more were killed in the Second World War. Citizens under totalitarian regimes became subjected to mass surveillance and censorhip. The Great Depression caused massive unemployment which led to gap between the rich and the poor.

Dystopian themes in this era focused on fear of state and loss of freedom caused by government propagandas and censorhip.
notable_event: Atomic Bombing in Nagasaki and Hiroshima

books.author: George Orwell
books.desc: People are subjected under the watchful eye of the state, where opinions are influenced by propaganda, and where the nation is in perpetual war against the enemies.

books.title: Brave New World
books.author: Aldous Huxley
books.desc: About a society where the truth is difficult to parse from within a vast sea of irrelevant information.

books.title: It Can't Happen Here
books.author: Sinclair Lewis
books.desc: a cautionary tale about the fragility of democracy, an alarming, eerily timeless look at how fascism could take hold in America.
